div.l: The streme of lif nowe droppith on̄ the Chymbe
The sely tunge may well rynge and Chymbe
Of wrecchidnesse that ys passed full yore
With olde folke save dotage is nomore
When̄ that oure hoste had harde this sermonyng
He began̄ to speke as lordely as a kyng
And seide what a mountith all this witte
Whi shull we all day speke of holy writte
The devill made a Reve forto preche
Or a Sowter a Shipman̄ or a leche
Sey furth thy tale and tary not the tyme
Lo Depford and it is half wey to pryme
bHit were all tyme thy tale for to begynne Transposition of 53-54 corrected by "ba" marks in the margin.
Lo Grenewiche there many a shrewe is ynne
Nowe sires quod this Oswolde the Reve
Y pᵃray you all that ye not greve
Though y aunswere and somdell sette his hove
For lefull is with force · force of shove
This drunken̄ Millere hath tolde vs here
Hou that that begiled was a Carpentere
Paraventure in scorne for y am̄ one
And by youre leve y shall hym̄ quyte anone
Right in his Cherles t̉ermes woll y speke
I pray to god his necke mot to breke
He can̄ well in myn̄ ye se a stalke
But in his owne he cannot see a Balke
Hic incipit fabula p̉ropositi
At Trumpyngton̄ not fer fro Caumbrigge
There goith a broke and oủere that a Brigge
Vppon̄ the which broke there standith a Mille
And this is verrey sothe that y you telle
A Millere was there dwellyng many a day
As eny Pecok he was proude and gay
Pipe he coude and fisshe a nettys bete
And turne Cuppes and well wrastle and shete
Ay by his belte he bare a longe panade
And of a a swerde ful trenchaunt was the blade
